data.question: What is the molecular formula of the compound Rh2(espn)2Cl?
At what temperature (K) was the X-ray crystal structure of [Rh2(espn)2]BF4 determined?
What is the space group of Na[Rh2(espn)2(NClTs)2] as determined by X-ray crystallography?
How does the absorption correction method used for Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) differ from that used for Rh2(espn)2?
data.answer: Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) used Multi-scan, SADABS, while Rh2(espn)2 did not specify the method.

data.question: What is the relationship between the crystal size of Rh2(espn)2Cl obtained from concentrated CH3CN at 0°C and at -35°C?
data.answer: The crystal size obtained at -35°C (0.3 x 0.2 x 0.03 mm) is smaller than that obtained at 0°C (0.35 x 0.15 x 0.03 mm).

data.question: Based on the X-ray crystal structures provided, which compound has the highest molecular weight?
data.answer: 2(C36H50N6O4Rh2)·2(BF4)·2(C4H10O)·4(C2H3N) with a molecular weight of 2159.35 g/mol.

data.question: Is the crystal system of Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) the same as that of [Rh2(espn)2]BF4 obtained from vapor diffusion of CH3CN in Et2O?
data.answer: No, Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) is triclinic, P¯1, while [Rh2(espn)2]BF4 from vapor diffusion is monoclinic, P21/n.

data.question: Does the compound Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) exhibit a higher absorption correction μ (mm–1) value compared to Rh2(espn)2?
data.answer: False, Rh2(espn)2(NTsCl) has a μ value of 0.75 mm–1, while Rh2(espn)2 has a μ value of 0.78 mm–1.

data.question: Is the volume (V) of the unit cell for Na[Rh2(espn)2(NClTs)2] larger than that of Rh2(espn)2?
data.answer: True, Na[Rh2(espn)2(NClTs)2] has a V of 2819.6 Å3, while Rh2(espn)2 has a V of 2270.3 Å3.

data.question: Does the compound [Rh2(espn)2]BF4 obtained from layering THF with toluene have a higher number of observed reflections [I > 2σ(I)] compared to the same compound obtained from vapor diffusion of CH3CN in Et2O?
data.answer: False, the compound obtained from vapor diffusion has 9174 observed reflections, while the one from layering THF with toluene has 8749 observed reflections.
